description.narrative: Increased numbers of early-career scientists in Low- and Lower Middle-Income Countries have produced good quality research that can be put into use by 2021.

International Foundation for Science (IFS) var bland de första organisationerna som uttryckligen riktade sina insatser mot yngre forskare i utvecklingsländer och deras behov. IFS är ett forskningsråd och registrerad som en enskild organisation i Sverige. Sida har sedan starten 1974 varit den största givaren. Sida stödet möjliggör att genom forskningsanslag från IFS kan unga forskare kan bedriva relevant forskning av hög kvalité inom området hållbar förvaltning av naturresurser i låg- och medelinkomstländer. Förutom tilldelning av forskningsanslag stöder IFS kapacitetshöjande aktiviteter som feedback på forskningsförslag, vetenskaplig rådgivning, praktisk utbildning i tematiska workshops, forskningsfärdighetskurser, mentorskap, studiebesök till avancerade laboratorier, utbildningar inom service och underhåll av utrustning samt assistans med inköp av vetenskaplig utrustning och vetenskaplig förbrukningsmaterial.
Det finns ett stort behov av stöd till forskning inom området hållbar förvaltning av naturresurser i utvecklingsländerna. IFS program syftar till att stärka unga forskares förmåga i utvecklingsländer att bedriva ändamålsenlig och högkvalitativ forskning relevant för utvecklingsländer. IFS programmet har utvärderats fem gånger; de senaste två gånger under 2010 och 2012. Den senaste utvärderingen var fokuserad på att analysera två aspekter av IFS verksamhet. Den första var att beskriva processen för utveckling av den nya IFS strategin för 2011-2020. Den andra var att analysera vilken roll skulle IFS:s nya strategin kunna spela i u-länder där forskningskapacitets scenario förändras snabbt med tanke på IFS relevans, effektivitet och hållbarhet. Utvärderingen konstaterar att IFS:s mandat fortfarande är relevant och IFS har presterat mycket bra resultat. Stipendiaternas internationella publikationer har ökat i antal, forskarna har fått en ökad trovärdighet på sina heminstitutioner och ökad kredibilitet bland andra forskningsråd. Forskarna har också fått ökad kunskap om hur man hanterar forskningsprojekt och några projekt har lett till utveckling av ny teknik och nya produkter. Som resultat av ovannämnda prestationer har IFS-stödda forskare blivit befordrade till högre befattningar.
Ett beredningsbeslut (2013-001461) hade fattats den 13 maj 2013 att bereda stöd till IFS under 2014-2018 med totalt 90 miljoner kr. IFS inkom med en ansökan enligt Sidas instruktioner den 10 okt 2013 för ett 5 årigt stöd. Sida har analyserat IFS planer, budgeten och resultatramverket för fem år, men på grund av utrymmesskäl i Sida/FORSK bemyndiganderam kan i dagsläget endast beslutta om stöd för tre år (2014-2016).

description.narrative:
IFS have continued their important work of supporting early career researchers in low- and lower-middle income countries by giving out research grants and conducting capacity enhancing activities.
The annual report of 2020 to Sida shows that IFS activities have been implemented as planned.
Grants:
Grants in 2020 were given in the following three research areas:
- Biological Resources in Terrestrial Systems
- Water and Aquatic Resources
- Food Security, Dietary Diversity and Healthy Livelihoods
Out of the 2112 applications, after review and selection, 116 applicants were awarded grants. Out of these grants 12 were renewal grants (renewal grants were given under the old strategy in 2020).
Of those awarded, 45% dealt with biological resources in terrestrial systems, 20% with water and aquatic resources, and 35% with food security, dietary diversity and healthy livelihoods. The IFS Secretariat also processed 47 purchase orders for laboratory equipment and materials.
Women scientists represented 40% of the individual research grant awardees and men 60%. In addition to the early career scientists receiving research grants, the other 1,498 applicants were given feedback by well-qualified IFS reviewers and advisors as part of their capacity-enhancing support.
The year 2020 was one of transition from the previous strategy (2011-2020) to the new strategy (2021-2030).
The following changes have been applied in the new strategy for the basic grant:
- Applications are no longer accepted in French
- Applicants need to be either PhD holders or should be enrolled in a PhD programme (MSc holders no longer eligible)
- The grant size increased from 12000 to 15000 USD
Advanced grants will be given under the new strategy (up to US$20 000). These are still under discussion and no advanced grants were given in 2020.
Grants are normally followed up 4 years after they have been awarded which means that grants given in 2016 were followed up in 2020:
In the report to Sida IFS present 13 impactful projects from 2016 to highlight how grantees research is being put into use; and to show the representation of topics, countries, regions, women and men. The scientists have so far published 43 articles in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and they have established 336 national and international scientific contacts. The impact of the 2016 grantees research projects is described in the report and demonstrates the breadth of the research being done by the grantees.
Capacity-enhancing Support: In 2020, IFS was jointly engaged with a variety of strategic partners across a spectrum of topics (including communication to a non-scientific audience, Covid, food security, freshwater tenure rights, 'soft skills' for scientists, water and agricultural systems, and women in science). These 13 activities took place virtually.
IFS provided mentoring support to the ongoing research projects of 433 grantees, along with those finishing up (72 individual and 40 collaborative grants from 2016). IFS also supported their alumni to associate and support other potential grantees through training and coaching. A webinar series was launched to strengthen the science capacity of early career researchers in Africa in the post-covid world, and an introductory meeting was arranged with new women grantees.
Covid-19 response: IFS appear to have adapted their work swiftly to the Covid-19 pandemic. They have shifted many activities to a digital forum. They appear to have managed this transition well, at the same time handling the normal workload and managing the discussions regarding IFS future.
Discussions relating to the future of IFS: In 2019 it was decided that Sida should either commit long-term funding to support the implementation of IFS' new strategy, or provide phase-out support depending on how successful IFS is in attracting funding. Extensive discussions were held internally at Sida during 2020 and 2021, the matter was discussed at the Sida Scientific Advisory Board (SSAB) in October and December 2020.
The main factors in favour of continued support are:
- IFS is a well-established organisation with an extensive network of scientists. There is a lot of goodwill that the organisation capitalises on.
- The work of IFS is relevant and of high quality there is a need to support early career researchers. Responses to the calls are high and awardees state that the grants have been instrumental in their career. According to the awardees the funds often generate matching funds. Even though the grants are small (typically USD 12,000 over 2-3 years) recipients state that they have a large impact.
- Feedback on the proposal is given to both successful and unsuccessful applicants. There is a large capacity building component in this, although it is labour intensive.
- The Board of Trustees (BOT), the members of scientific advisory committees (SAC) as well as the over 1100 scientific advisors, work pro-bono for IFS. This is a very positive sign of commitment.
- The evaluation (2018) concluded that the overall performance in quantitative terms of targets and achievements is good.
The following areas are considered problematic:
Low cost efficiency:
- According to the evaluation (2018): With operational costs ranging from 44% (2015) to 56% (2017) for running of the organisation and the scientific review process and courses, the efficiency of the overall system is clearly low. It cannot be justified by the positive effects which the scientific reviews have on research capacity building. Options for increasing efficiency: increasing grant level, simplify review process, webinars instead of courses, delegate more to the South.
- In its present design and composition IFS is still a largely western-based organisation. The IFS Secretariat is in Stockholm and a large majority of SAC members are from Europe (65% are from Europe and only 16% are from Africa where most of the research proposals come from). The dialogue with emerging research funding platforms e.g. in Africa, or with the private sector also investing in the South is weak.
- Dependency on Sida is high approximately 65% of funds come from Sida. Despite intensive efforts IFS have not managed to increase the funding base. On the contrary, decreased funding from Sida (meant to force IFS to seek funding elsewhere) resulted in decreased funding from other funders.
- There is no effective monitoring of what happens on the ground, once the grants are provided. Monitoring is based on what is reported by the grantees (evaluation 2018).
- The IFS approach is more individualised and short-term compared with other contributions supported by Sida. Once a grant is provided IFS provides little monitoring, mentoring or follow-up. Alumni organisations are operational in a few countries only.
- Sustainability: Many of the staff at IFS are close to retirement age. The organisation has been shrinking over the years and now has significantly fewer staff than before. The young generation is not represented in the BOT and practices used for many years are not challenged (evaluation 2018).
- IFS rejected many of the findings in the evaluation from 2018 and did not address recommendations perceived by Sida as being relevant (such as the matter of cost-effectiveness and shifting the focus from giving feedback to applicants to supporting grantees).
After discussions internally at Sida, with IFS and with the SSAB it was decided that phase-out support for IFS should be prepared. The low cost efficiency achieved by IFS and lack of other funders were deciding factors. Phasing out support from Sida to IFS effectively means that the organisation in its current form will shut down. Follow-up discussions have been held with IFS and they are preparing a proposal for phase-out support (2022-2024). During this time IFS will close their operations in Stockholm, ensure that grantees that have been promised an opportunity to apply for a follow-up grant will be given an opportunity to apply and complete all follow-up.
Sida considers that the grants are a valuable form of support and there is a need to support early career researchers with these relatively small grants. The grants often generate matching funds and awardees state that these grants have been instrumental for their research career. The possibility of IFS transferring their activities to another organisation has been discussed and IFS have stated that that they wish to follow this path. A study has been procured by IFS and a team were contracted in October 2021 to carry out the study. Sida has had input on the ToR and has been present (as an observer) at meetings to evaluate proposals for the study.
The study is due to be finalised in early 2022.
